Entry.1:
In Indian Ocean. Arabian Sea - En route Colombo to Aden.
Fancy dress ball on board to see Old Year out & New Year in. Soft drinks only allowed
Entry.2: Off Lakadive islands during middle of the day
Entry.3:
Read Mass - Ordinary of - over in morning
 Rosary & litany at 8 p.m.
Entry.4:
Much interested in the Account inExodus of the wanderings of the Israelites from Cairo, through theSinai Peninsula, up & down, then through the lands of Moab & others to Jericho in the promised land.
Arrived Suez about 10 p.m. Ships & lights in the town.
Entry.5:
Read about Suez & the Canal in Baedecker. Finished letters to Girls Mollie & others Posted them.
Left Suez at 12-30 p.m. Soldiers mostly from India, on every yard of the canal at night. Working on defences during the day.

Wednesday 13 January 1915
Arrived Port Said sometime early this morning. 9am. Coaling
Journey through Canal without a stop from Suez to Port Said 12.30pm to 12.30am. 
early morning
 12-1-15 to
Entry.6:
Went ashore at Port Said from 2 p.m. to 
4
3-45 p.m.
Left Port Saidfor Alexandria at 5-30 p.m.
Studying French from 8-45 to 9-30 p.m.
Entry.7:
Arrived at Alexandria 9am.Tied to buoy in harbour awaiting orders.
0.40 am. Mails came on board. Wondering are there letters for me. not likely.
Replied at once
 Letter from Joseph . Replied at once & posted on ship.
Posted letters to Mollie, the M. J. of A. N. 
Many went on shore intending to go to Cairo tonight. All the Mc mc'ers.
Entry.8:
Still tied up to the buoy in the harbour. O.C. away. Not on shore so far 12 noon. Wire from O.C. this morning re men & danger of infection.
O.C. not returned at 11-55 p.m. Col Ramsay Smith & other senior officers away. Lieut. Col. Maudsley only other Colonelon the boat.
Entry.9:
9 a.m. - O.C. & other Senior officers, except Maudsley, away on shore during the afternoon. Lunch at KhedivialClub. Drove round City, to Pompeys pillar, &Katacombs. &c. Back at 6 pm.
Orders to disembark & go to Cairo as soon as possible.
Entry.10:
7-30 am Kyarraat Wharf.
12.noon. Baggage being packed now for removal to Cairo. At Jesuits College. Magnificent.
Baggage put on train for Cairo.
Entry.11:
Morning at Casino at St Stephano, an ex prison building on the outskirts of Alexandria which is being convtd into a hospital for reception of wounded Indian (Hindoostan) troops from Europe Indian medical officers in charge.
Lunched with Dr& Mrs Morisson & his wife. He an 
Abed
 Aberdonian, she aScotch mixture of some kind, born at Suez.
During afternoon at Germanhospital Deaconesseswith Dr Wilmott assistant to Dr Morisson. Most interested in the magnificent institution. All sorts of coloured patients. Splenectomy &cDined at mess club.
Entry.12:
Posted letters to Girls & others . Lunch at the Khedivial Club after writing letters. Visited Jesuits College, saw over it. From roof saw small hill under which Alexander the Great is said to have been buried, a mosque is on the spot now. Was pointed out landing place of Napoleon 1st in 1798, & the route he took to get behind the city & his entry in that point.
Called on the Franciscans at St. Catherines Church. A richly embelished church. Some women praying. Many secondary altars.
Went to Patrician brothers. Showed me over theirschool. A spacious well appointed building. Up to date in every particular. Delivered two addresses, one to the seniors in the litterary division, another to the 
juniors
 seniors in the commercial division. Physics laboratory. Church. organ. Wash basins Dormitories.
Entry.13:
8-15 a.m. Left Alexandria in charge of No. 2 Hospital. Arrived Cairo at 11-45a.m. Arrived Mena House, The pyramids, Cairo about 2p.m. Camp 
d
 to be erected at once. Senior officers and Nurses settled at Mena House.
Pyramids straight in front of the room in which I am writing & where I shall sleep.
Bed at 11 p.m.
Entry.14:
At Mena House
Everyone working hard getting hospitals into working order
Entry.15:
Same as Thursday
Two operations,inguial hernias
Entry.16:
Camp being erected rapidly. Officers & men working very well, especially Major Read, Captain Mackenzie, and Captain Clayton.
Col. Springthorpe officious & boyrish as usual. Young officers slow & not punctual
Entry.17: Camp ready for inspection. Major General Bridges inspected the camp at11-15 am. Said "excellent". Not able to be at Mass. €“Operation.
Entry.18:
Administrative work
ed
 as 
O.C.
 Acting O.C.
Work at hospital.
Surgeon General Ford called.Interviewed Major Millard, Col. House, J.B.N. & some Nurses. Did not inspect the hospital
Entry.19:
Working about hospitals, here & 
on
at the camp.
Operations.
Egyptian doings & people as usual.
First word of attack on the Suez canal by Turkish outposts
Col.Martin came tonight.
Entry.20:
Col. Martin 
came
 took over from me today, this relieves me from the Administrative duties and will allow me more time for study, surgical work and reading.
Posted letters home.
Entry.21:
Operating & about the hospital till 4 p.m.
At 4 p.m. went with Col. Springthorpe to Cairo. Dinner at Sheppherds. Afterwards at the Monled El-Nabi (Prophet Mahomeds Birthday) celebrations at Abbassieh in Cairo. Much illumination by oil & electric lamps, and fireworks. A big crowd. Special hut for officers.
Entry.22:
About hospital. Acting for the O.C. during the middle & early afternoon parts.
Walked to top of hill to thesouth of the hotel. Had a talk with Dr. from Cairo who has a small chalet on the apex of the hill, the door looks straight at the side (Northern I think) of the great pyramid.
Entry.23:
Small operations during the day.
Walked around the pyramids, and to the Sphynx during the afternoon 4-30 to 6-20 p.m.
Met Alexr Begbie, son of David Begbie of Plattsburg.
Entry.24:
Mass at 9 a.m in Camp. Father McAuliffe celebrant, he preached a simple sermon.
Reading & writing all day.
Entry.25:
1915
Six minor operations today. Varicocele. Axillary Abscess. Circumcissions (2), tonsils. Stricture.
Dined with Col. Braund €“2nd Infty Battallion at 6pm. Walked to pyramids & Sphynx withSister?between 9 & 10-15 pm. Moon 
not
 behind the clouds. Sat under jaw of Sphynxfor ten minutes.
Posted letters home & many postcards.
Entry.26:
Some operations.
Reading & writing all day.
Some reading
Entry.27:
Operations this morning. 2 hernias. 1 appendix. 1 Mastoid 1 Empyema.
Asked DrBird to be present, he came.
At 4-15 pm. set out for the great Pyramid. Climbed it down at 5-45 p.m. Name carved in the Stone as usual.
Visited DrAdam Scheuber, of Cairo, at his Chalet above Mena House, at 6 p.m.
Entry.28:
Hospital in the morning.
Writing & reading most of the day
Walked to top of sand hills just before dinner.
Air very cold.
Expected letters but none came.
Entry.29:
One operation this morning Haemorrhoids
A beautiful morning 12 noon.No letters
In Cairo during the afternoon
At Heliopolis for half an hour.
Shepheards to dine with Major Barrett.
Left for home at 10.30 pm.

Saturday 6 February 1915
At Mena House all day.
Working, writing, and reading
10.45 p.m. Must go to bed early.

Sunday 7 February 1915
Mass. 9 a.m. Padre McAuliffe preached against use ofimmodestprofane & vulgar words in use about Camp.
Called 3rd & 4th InftyBattalion L. Col Owen L. Col. Onslow Thompson also 1st F Ambulance L Col. Newmarch.
Col Beeston & other officers, from the
Entry.30: Exped. force visited Mena House. They are camped at Heliopolis
Entry.32:
a.m.€“ The Pyramids as usual bathed in Sun. clouds often are overhead here, to an Australian portending rain, but the precious drops, never fall. The sands of the desert are filled with water worn stones from the size of a fist to the minutest particles. Large stonesare white in colour & not water worn. Must ask someone about them.
Climbed the pyramidthis afternoon for the 2nd time. No difficulty. The sunsetgorgeous from the top.
Entry.34:
Heavy clouds in the East breaking up from the North. In Australia one would say €“ Heavy rain within one hour.
Everything quiet in a surgical way.

Wednesday 10
Entry.35:
One operation. Left Inguinal hernia this morning.
A letter dated "6th January 
from
Moss Vale" from Mollie. Replied to it at once.
In Cairo for dinner with Dr. P. Fiaschi - Prof Watson the third. At a Music Hall afterwards.Ordinary show.
Caught 12 midnight tram back to Mena House.

Thursday 11February 1915
Ordinary days work.
Surgeon General Williams here between 3 & 4 p.m. Looks as well as ever he did, even thirty years ago.
Letters from Car , Joseph , Kitty , Doffie & Mr Clarence Bridge.
Walk around excavations atbaseWest of great pyramid.
Entry.36:
rdinary duties during the day. Prof Watson left a card for me.
Walked around the excavations during the evening.
Letters
Entry.37:
Ordinary duties.
Op. appendicectomy
during
at 3-45 p.m.
Wrote to Car, Joe & Kitty
Entry.38:
Mass at Mena House 6.30 a.m. Attended
Work all day Walk over sands during 5-30 to 6-15 pm.
Entry.39:
Two appendix operations & one hernia this morning.
About hospital all day.
Posted letters to the Girls, Matron Sherwood, and Doffie Williams.
Walk about 6 pm.
Entry.40:
February1915
One appendix operation
Busy all day.
Atmospheric conditions ideal.
Walk around Native village during afternoon. Dirt in excelsis.
Entry.41:
February1915
3 operations - 2 Haemorrhoids & 1 fistula inano.
In Cairo and at Heliopolis with Colonel Martin.
At a conference re Neisserian affection at The Palace, Heliopolis;General Williams presided.
Col. Braund, Major Scobie, Father McAuliffe, dined with us at Mena House.
Ordinary hospital work.
Entry.42:
About hospital all day
Letters from Car , Joseph , Kitty , and Mr McDonald.
Operations &c
Walk on sand hills.

Friday 19
Entry.43:
Operations
MrsNewmarch,MrsHarry Chisholm, MissChristian,Miss Chirinside Miss ,Col. Ryan, & Lieut. McLennan to 
tea
 afternoon tea at Mena House
Entry.44:
Busy all day in hospital, operations &c
Posted letters to girls, Molly, Macdonald, Paton, and Peck.
Walk to top of sand hill

Sunday 21
Entry.45:
Not too O.K. today.
Went withJerrom this afternoon to the Zoological Gardins.Giraffes brown withsome white. Magnificent. Monkeys varied & interesting.No dinner, asleep on couch

"All places that the eye of heaven visits
Are to a wise man ports & happy havens".
Richard II-1-3

Monday 22
Entry.46:
Not very well this morning.
One operation. Varicose veins of the Short saphena.
Emergency opn. No 55 this evening, long and difficult.
Improved in health during the afternoon, ate a little atdinner.
Wrote Drs Arthur, & Flynn, & Col. Fallon

Tuesday 23
Entry.47:
Ordinary duties today.
Prof Watson here during the afternoon.
Inspection of the hospital by a Surgeon General Baptsie or some such name. A smart capable man, his aide a L. Col., junior a major of the R.A.M.C
Entry.48:
TheSuns rays possessmore heat today.
Sent pictures & post cards to the girls.
Ordinary duties.
Two operations during the morning
Wrote to Sir. J. Carruthers, Strickland, Drury, H. D. MacIntosh, Alec Begbie , MrsTrefle.
Entry.49:
Wrote Delargie & Buckley & Hopenden. Mat. Harris. 
T
he Girls
 General Williams. MrsM. M. Knowles.
General work.
Emptying the hospital, preparatory to shifting Camp to some other part of the world.
Rode on a Camel to the Sphynx & back8. P.T. 

Friday 26
Entry.50:
Posted letters to the Girls. 1½ P.T. stamps.
Day as the other days.
All my patients can leave the hospital at any moment except one Empyema.
Letter from Dr Harris, & New Year Card from A.F.N.A people of Syd.
Dinner at 8 p. m. with Dr Adam Scheuber, a native of Riga, Russia - sharia-el-Genaineh. An educated gentleman. Enjoyed the dinner immensley. the fowl& parsley sauce, & the peche Melba .
home at 1 a.m.
Entry.51:
Saturday 27February 1915
Wrote to Dr H. L.Harris. WimereuxFrance.
Wrote Mrs Fraser.Thorn Bank, Cedar Hill, Newport, Isle of Wight.
Dined at The Chalet on top of Sand hill above Mena House with Dr Scheuber
Entry.53:
Mass at 9 a.m. At Museum of Egyptian Antiquities during the afternoon.
Beastly sick. Recovered about midnight.
Wrote Geo Reid, Dr Arthur, Dr Paton, Mrs Huxley, Roger Arnott, Clarrie Bridge, Dr Fox,J. Roach, and The girls.
Entry.54:
My wards in the hospital practically empty today.
St. Davids day & Hy Vth IV-7-101 to 108.
Everything points to us moving at an early date from here
Not well today.
The food here, eggs, cellery, onions, turnips, and these garnituresround thevarious insip meats are horrid. I would not live here for all the mud in Egypt
Entry.56:
Wards still emptying.
At 11-30 p.m. left Mena House with Jerrom and eleven nurses & a guide for Sakkarah. Two camels and Twelve donkeys. I rode one donkey, "Telegraph" by name, there & back, being at least 16 miles across the desert (8 miles each way). The donk. a pleasant little beast to ride travels quite as rapidly as a camel. Carried my weight quite well.
The tombs of the hills at Sakkarah, the most remarkable subjects viewed by me in Egypt. their weight & size, their being of granite, the lids. how they were got into position after coming down the river five hundred miles. Mirabile dictu. Very sick in my belly on arrival home.
Entry.57:
March 1915
Much improved this morning, yet able to eat but little.
Obtained Charcoal and pepsine tablets, have takena few, hope they may do me good
Ordinary work about hospital.
Dr Schuber
t
 called to see me. Very good of him.
Entry.58:
About hospital all day.
Very seedy. 

Made a mistake in a day JBN
Entry.59:
9 a.m.

About hospitalall day
Letter from Joseph. Posted in Sydney on 15-1-15 dated15-1-15.
Answered at once.
Major Gray at Sakkara.

Notable to Eat.
Interior upset, gaseous, making me miserable

Friday 5March 1915
Made a mistake in a day JBN
Entry.60:
9. am

Aet my first good breakfast for two weeks, porridge & sausages (vinegar & mustard) bread, tea.
Posted letters to Girls & Mollie.
Colonel away during the morning.

 6. Saturday (65-300)
Morning, as others here "perfect in atmospheric conditions.
Writing & reading & hospital work all day

Sunday 7March 1915
Wrote Mrs Reardon & Jessie Kennedy.
Not a Mass today, had to attenda parade at 9 am.
Reading & writing all day
Entry.61:
Letters posted to The Girls, Mollie, Dr Arnott,Miss Garran, & one written to Maggie.
Busy about the hospital all day.
Saw the horses in the stable.
Dardanells being bombardedby the British & French fleets, have been for several days. How history is being made.
Entry.63:
At No I Hospital, The Palace, Heliopolis for dinner 6.30 pm. Antimolyat the Christian Brothers school at Fagabah.
Went on from No I Hospital to the Camp at Heliopolis (Col Smith gave me a car to go in), called upon Captn Fiaschi, Col. Beeston, Col. Monash, Col. McGlynn . Saw Colonel Burnage.
Home 11-45 pm

Wednesday 10
Entry.64:
Wrote Roach, Fred Flowers, the girls, FoxRoyal Artillery.
Abouthospital all day.
An Australian mail in, a letter from Senator Pearce to me, none from home.
Rode for one hour during the afternoon across the dessert

Thursday 11March 1915
Hot weather today.
2 p.m. No letters for me from home.
Rode for one hour midst the cultivated land, & the palm groves& the irrigated land on this side the hill
Left Mena House at 8.30 p.m. for the Heliopolis Camp. Arrived at the Camp at 11 pm
Entry.65:
Up 6 A.M. with Lieut. Col. McGlynn from W. Maitland. Started about 7-30 a.m. on divisional Manouver with Colonel Monash & his staff.
Outall day till 4-30 pm., riding all the time. Home Mena House 10.30 pm bath & bed officers & men still crude but plenty of good & fair officers there. GeneralMaxwell, Birdwood, Godlee , Bridges &c.
Entry.67:
Posted letters to 
Carrie
 the girls & Mollie. Replies to Car, Joseph & Kitty. Wrote reply to one from Doffie.Not outall day.
Rode during afternoon through the country.

Sunday 14
Entry.68:
At mass at 7 am. Rode
Visited the Barage across the Nile river about 2 miles below Cairo. It's used for conserving the water, that then may be distributed to the farmers (fellahas) throughout the whole of the Delta. Flood mittigation & water supply are the functions of the barrage. storage of water is thefunction of the Assouan dam.
The director of the Barage works showed Colonel Monash, Col. McGlynn, Captain McAuliffe, & Mr Smith over the place, with me.

Monday 15March 1915
Ride between 7 & 8 a.m.
Reading & writing all day
Wrote to P.J. MacNamara, Jack MacNamara & MrsPotts
A shower of rain this afternoon
Ride during the afternoon

Tuesday 16 March 1915
Letter from Joseph of date8.2.15 this morning. Answered it. Posted letters to Mollie, the Minister for Public Works Egypt, Clarence Bridge, The Admiralty London, Ivy Macdonald.
Wrote to M. M. Knowles, David Watkins.
Showers of rain during early morning & before mid-day.
Riding during Morning & afternoon.
Father McAuliffe gave me a shamrock plant from Limerick.

Wednesday 17
Entry.69:
Gave Col. Martinmost of the Shamrock plant which was given to me by Padre McAuliffe.
Received orders today that I was to be left in charge of Mena House when No 2 G.H. has departed.
Ride during the afternoon.
Quiet day in every respect.
Death of Major Parker from Diplococcal meningitis 
of Major Par
Came from W, Australia

Thursday 18March 1915
Ride before breakfast across dessert
Wrote to Royal College of Surgeons. Dr Paton. Dr Peck.
O.C. away for most of the day, in charge during his absence.
Received copy of The Times from Dr Peck of date
Entry.70:
Wrote to
 Ride during afternoon, along the Canal banks.

Friday 19
Entry.71:
Not out this morning
Birth of Dr Livingstone 1813.
Wrote to Lieut Gordon Bennett, The Minister forEducation, Egypt, The Christian Brothers St Catherines Alexandria.
Wrote some sheets for the Girls & Mollie
Writing & studying French all day long.
No surgical work to do.
Entry.73:
Riding before breakfast.
At sports of No 2 Battn.during the afternoon. Much drunkenessamongst officers & men.
Wrote to Senator Pearce, Fred Flowers, Girls & Mollie.
Letter from Dr Dunlop adviser to 
Minstry
 Ministry for Education.
Entry.74:
Mass at 7 a.m €“ Gallop across dessert thereafter.
Po Csto Sir G. Strickland, Girls, Mollie, Posted letters to them.
Wrote to Mrs M. M. Knowles & posted letter. Wrote to Mr Begg Old South Head RoadBondi€“Father to a lad I operated on in the hospital. v. Note book No
For a ride through the farm lands between 5 p.m. & 6.30 p.m.
Entry.75:
Wrote 
Commenced letters to Girls & Mollie.
Wrote to Dr Dunlop, Educational adviser, to the Egyptian Government re visiting schools.
Riding between 7 & 8 a.m.
Riding between 5 & 6-20 p.m. Went along the Cairo road.
Writing to Girls & reading after dinner.

Tuesday 23March 1915
Ride across dessert between 7 & 8 a.m.
Reading & working till 1p.m.
Two papers Table Talk & Sydney Mail War No XXIX from Mrs M. M. Knowles of Melbourne.
Riding during afternoon 5 p.m to 6-10 pm.

Wednesday 24
Entry.76:
Went Cairo by No 15 Ambulance waggon at 10 a.m. Called Ministry for Education. Spoke with Dr Dunlop (Educational advisor) & Mr Daniels (an inspector) chatted with them for half an hour. The former a Scotchman from Glasgow, Acute & Knowledgeable.
Went to a primary school under aegis of latter.Examined the classes of each year, four years in the course. Teaching in Arabic. Maps in Arabic ( British genius) Nile from origin to mouth. Mentioned to them Livingstone, Burton, Speeke, Baker, Stanley, Eunis Pash & their travels
Luncheon at 
Sheppehards
 Continental with Mrs Stokes. Went to Christian brothers school at Koronfishoff the Mouski (Principal Native Street in Cairo) St Josephs. Band played &c. To call again.
Sheppheards to dinner. Home 11 pm.

Thursday 25
Entry.77:
Ride between 7 & 8 a.m. Not well.Poor wine at St Joseph's upset me.
Went to the Competitions, 
at
in drill & physicalexercises,
at the
 beteween the Primary Schools of the Egyptian govmnt, at the Saidiehsecondary school from 4 to 6 pm. Six teams competed. 
Drill
 Dress neat, drill good,exercisesin some cases very good. TheUnder Sectyfor Education & many teachers present. Youngsters in the teams enthusiastic. Much applause from onlookers.
Home 7 p.m

Friday 26
Entry.78:
Writing& reading all day.
For a ride 
dur
 between 5 p.m & 6-20 pm. Across dessert, beyond the pyramids.
Had photograph taken of Morgan the Nubian land.
Photo taken of self at the Sphynx, on my horse

Saturday 27
Entry.79:
Ride before breakfast
Reading and writing most of the day
Posted letters to The Girls, Mollie Dr Armitt ,Ted Buckley, Dr Arthur. Paper,Wenkley Dispatchcame from Mrs Fraser (Mrs Bradley)
Ride during the afternoon.
Father McAuliffe called here during the morning.
Reading
Letter fromDorothy Williamsof date
Entry.80: It came via London & the Brit. W. deptmnt.
Entry.81:
Mass at 9 a.m. Father McAuliffe.Full Congration
A 
dust
 storm filled the air with sand all day, with the dusk & moon the wind fell & now 7-30 p.m.all is calm.
Not out during the day.
Wrote to Doffie Williams Mrs Knowles & comm letters to Mollie.
Entry.82:
On the plateau between 7 & 8 A.M.
8.30 pm. The dust coming again strongly it began
jus
 at 7-45 a.m. when I was galloping midst the splended air of the Lyssian plateau, blowing from the South. Are there high hills just to the southward?
One operation during the afternoon
Riding during the afternoon. An active horse that required a long gallop across thesand to steady him.

Tuesday 30
Entry.83:
Wrote to HaroldSparks,Goomeri Island.
Three operations thismorning
A hot dry day
Riding between 5. & 6. p.m.

Wednesday 31
Entry.84:
Ride before breakfast. Air warm. Locusts. Snails on shrubs, glued to stalk by gum at open End, Alabaster, bones human & other, petrified wood. Moisture deposited on stones before sun rise then evaporated by the sun light gives a coolnessto the atmosphere on the ridge of the plateau.
Ride during the afternoon across the cultivated lands. Looking at the Locusts on the banks of the Canals, where they were in large numbers 
being
 the females being impregnated, & it may be getting ready to deposit their eggs. The females are grey the males a bright yellow.
Entry.85:
Ride before breakfast.
About the hospital all day. Writing, reading, & sleeping.
Riding between 6 & 7 p.m.
Sent a cable to the girls at 8 p.m. Nash, Sydney. Happy Easter. Well. Love Cost 28.5 Milliemes

Friday 2
Entry.86:
Not riding this morning.
O.C. away during most of the day.
1st Brigade & other troops under orders to move out tomorrow.
Reading and writing all day
Entry.88:
About hospital most of the day
After dinner went with Dr Purdy to Cairo. At Continental & Sheppheards Hotels. Left Cairo by 11-45 pm tram.
1st Brigade Inf left camp & Cairo. Col MacLaurin, Col. Braund, Captain Maguire & others.

Sunday 4
Entry.89:
Wrote Holman, Flowers, Paton, Mrs Thompson (Cooma), Fallon, Father Perrin, Pat. Watt., The Girls.
2nd Brigade of Infty left Camp & Cairo
Ride during morning & afternoon

Monday 5
Entry.90:
A severe dust storm today. The wind began about 2 a.m and continued till about 6 p.m.
In Cairo for an hour. Spoke with General Williams at Shepheards hotel
Writing & reading all day.

Tuesday 6
Entry.91:
Acting O.C. today Colonel Martin away.
Letters from Car, Joe & Kitty.

Wednesday 7
Entry.92:
Acting O.C. today Colonel Martin at Alexandria
Letters from Mrs Fraser of New Port. Isle of Wight.

Thursday 8
Entry.93:
Acting O. C. todayColonel Martin at Alexandria 
Letters from Mrs Reardon of Lock Gur, Kilmallock Co. Limerick Ireland

Friday 9
Entry.94:
Colonel Martin returned at 12.30 pm. He took over duties of O.C.
Riding between5 &6-30 pm.
Letter from College of Surgeons & George Reid.

Saturday 10
Entry.95:
Colonel Martin away most of the day, acting O.C. for him
Not out during the day
Posted letters to Girls, Mollie & Doffie

Sunday 11
Entry.96:
Mass at 7-30 a.m. A padre from S.A., Adelaide diocese,a Tipperary man, officiated.
Wrote David Storey M.L.A. Randwick
Riding on dessert during the evening 1 hr 5-30 to 6-30 o'ck

Monday 12April 1915
7 to 8. a.m. riding across dessert 
Major Jackson appointed " Surgical Specialist" What does "Surgical Specialist' mean
Wrote to 
the
The Girls, Doffie & Maggie, Mrs Reardon Senator Pearce, Franki.
Entry.98:
Letter from & toMiss Sherwood of Rookwood hospital
X Operation €“Hernia inguinal at 9 am.
X 11 A.M. at the Saidiah School, shown round by the head master Mr Sharman, an Englishman.v plan, and photographs
X A the Freres school Kronfish, at 3 p.m.,an enjoyable afternoon. Flowers &c. Jerome with me.

Wednesday 14
Entry.99:
Ordinary work about the hospital.
Acting for the Colonel during his absence.
Not out during the day

Thursday 15April 1915
Attended to JBN. 10 a.m.
Report to O.C. re officers
Riding on plateau between 7 & 8 a.m.
Also between 5 & 6-30 p.m.
Reading, writing, & sleeping the remainder of the day.
Several copies of the D. Telegraph recd from Doffie Williams

Friday 16
Entry.100:
Riding morning & afternoon
Not out during the day otherwise.

Saturday 17
Entry.101:
Hospital. Reading and writing all day.
Went to the pyramid of Aborawash this evening, about 7 miles to the Westward along the dessert.

Sunday 18
Entry.102:
Mass at 7-30 a.m.
Reading & writing all day
Ride between 5 & 6-30 p.m.
Concert in hall between 7-30 & 9 p.m.
Entry.103:
Colonel away all day, acting for him. Not Satisfactory but I try hard to make the show go along straight lines.
Writing & reading most of the day.
A 5-30p.m. paid a visit to Shei Gabri at Mena Village. A rich trader. I suppose that he took me down with some beads & carnelions

Tuesday 20
Entry.104:
Colonel Martin away most of the day today acting for him.
Wrote to R. D. Meagher, Hon Hy. Willis, Surgeon General Ford, Ramsay-Smith and 
M. Venizelos, Ex. Greek Premiere, visited Cairo to-day, he & the King differed over the war, he resigned, hinc illae lachyra 
Ride towards Sackkara between 5 & 6-30 p.m., visited two pyramids
Entry.105:
Letter to the Sultan and to Lady McMahon.
At the Medical school in Cairo during the morning with Dr Keating, & his staff of teachers
At the Citadel during the afternoon, visited the Mosque,
At Heliopolis Palace Hospital & dined with Col. Ramsay Smith & Major Barrett Home at 10p.m.

Thursday 22
Entry.106:
Working all the morning. Letter to Mrs Hughes (schoolteacher), "Airlie", Chatswood, N. S. Wales.
Writing & reading all day
Acting for the O.C. during his absence.
B.W.Hosp Salvarsan named Kharsivan & Neokharsivan

Friday 23
Entry.107:
Operation for Varicocele this morning.
Ride on the plateau between 7 & 8 a.m. Collected some alabaster. Air of the best.
Wrote to Dr D. Dunlop, Ed. dptmnt. in Cairo.
Ride across the dessert during the morning.

Saturday 24
Entry.108:
Saw General Ford at 10 a.m. He was corteous and civil, & I have hopes that he will bring to me relief. Good.
Back at Mena at 2-15 p.m.
At The Medical school till 1-30 pm. Saw some specimens & looked through some journals. Very good.

Sunday 25
Entry.109:
Mass at 7-30 a.m. in Light horse lines.
Ride between 5 & 6-45 p.m.
Reading & writing rest of day.
Day of the gallant charge of the Australians at Anzac Cove, Galipoli. A great feat of arms

Monday 26
Entry.110:
Worked till 3 a.m. at French
Wrote Prof David, John Travers, Col. Fiaschi, M. M. Bertrand, General Ford,
Note:/On Saturday posted letters to F.Flowers, John Estell, R. D. Meagher, Hon. D. Watkins, Senator de Largie, (Hon. WmGrahame 
p
 a congratulatoryletter). The Girls. Mollie. Wrote & posted to Bro. L. Mariuz €“ College des Freres.
Australians fighting at Gallipoliin great style.

Tuesday 27
Entry.111:
Colonel Martin away during the day 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Acting for him.
Riding about pyramids from 5.30 to 6.30pm.
Called on Dr Reisner €“The man from Harvard University, U.S.A., who excavates & has been doing so farnearly 20 years to the west of the Grand Pyramid. He returned a few days ago from up the Nile. where he has been since January of this year. Must call again.

Wednesday 28
Entry.112:
Colonel Martin in Cairo from 11 a.m. to 10 p.m., acting here for him.
At 5-15 p.m. climbed the pyramid Chephren. A silk handkerchief on the top said to have been placed there by the New Zealand troops when they were first encamped here.
Little difficulty in getting to the top. Three guides with me. Cut NASH into one stone on summit.

Thursday 29
Entry.113:
Letter from Car, Joseph, Kitty, DrMadon,of Lidcome, & a postcard from Mr Neil Macdonald.
Report re officers
Letter from General Ford re new appointmt for me. He phoned me during the afternoon & said that he was appointing me to a command. I cried content Acting for Colonel Martin all day. When he returned I showed him General Fords letter & asked him why he had been souncivil to me since I joined the hospital. He replied because he was told in Sydneythat I was trying for his position. Liar
Entry.115:
200 wounded arrived at Mena House today from the Dardanells. Various were the severity of the injuries. nearly all were bullet or shrapnell wounds of the legs and arms Removed first bullet of those in No 2 G. H. from an arm
Acting O.C. for the Colonel from 11 am. to 6.30p.m.
Entry.116:
7.15 to 8 a.m. riding on Plateau
Acting as O.C. during the day from 10 a.m. to 7 p.m.
Wounded pouring in all day from Gallipoli. Wrote up my cases and removed some bullets.
Posted letters to Girls, Mollie & D. Watkins
Entry.117:
May 1915
No mass to day.
Acting as O.C. 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.
Cases doing fairly well.
p
Entry.118:
3.30 p.m. today at the Christian Bros. school Koronfish, Cairo.
Letters posted toFiaschi Col Dr McDonald, Dr Arthur, Dr Paton, Neil Macdonald, Dr Peck, F. Flowers, Senator Pearce, Strickland, de Largie Fiaschi and .
Letter to Col. Martin re signing questions & answers.
Order at 6.45 p.m. from Colonel Ford to be at Abassia Barracks tomorrow morning at 10 o'clock to take charge.
Entry.120:
9-15 a.m. Left No 2 G.H. at Mena House & went to Abbassia to take charge of Abbassia Detention Barracks V. Hospital. A rotten game but General Ford asked me to do & I said that I would if he so desired.
Arrived Abbassia D. H. at 10 a.m. Found two medical officers there & Some details. Started at once to get matters ready.

Wednesday 5May 1915
Getting matters ready all day at the Abbassia D.B.H. Requisitions &c.
Letters from Mrs Abbott & HughDr MacIntosh
By myself in a room,formerly a stable, writing this up.
Weather beautiful
Entry.121:
Report re officers today

At Abassia all day. Two patients admitted.
Wrote lettersRobt. Paton & Mrs Knowles & Mrs Fraser.
Had meals with Captain Williams.
Entry.123:
Christian Brothers school at Koranfish today 3 or 3-30p.m.
At Abbassia D. BHospital nearly all day waiting for patients.
Meals with Captain Williams.

Saturday 8May 1915

at A. D. B. Hospital all day
Inspection by General , Duke Prince of Battenburg, Marquis of Anglesey, Surgeon Gen. Ford,and others.
In town at night. Club. Ruisall. and home.
Entry.124:
Mass at Heliopolis
At Mena House during afternoon.

Posted letters to John Meagher, Mrs Franki, P.J. MacNamara, Girls, Mollie, Mr Abbott, John Buchanan. Ted Buckley Mrs M. M. Knowles. Mrs Fraser Dr Paton. Editor of Gazette
Entry.125:
Sent 2 bottles of Champagne to Col Martin today in payment for bet made some time ago. saying that we should be away from Mena meaning Egypt by 9th May 1915
Ride between 7 & 8 am.
About 12 patients came in up to 6 p.m. today. Some forty patients bewteen 6 & 7 pm
In town for 1 hour at eight.
Entry.127:
About the Hospital all day.
Patients coming & going all day.
Everything all right
A good assistant in Captain Plant not lazy, or too Swell.

Wrote to F.Fletcher, Col Martin, & Rene Silk

Wednesday 12
Entry.128:
Ride before breakfast

Posted letters F. Fletcher, Col Martin , Rene Silk.

Not out during the day. 

Reading & writing, & attending to patients all the day

Thursday 13
Entry.129:
Ride between 7 & 8-15 P.M.
Found the Obelisk at Matarreiaha . Went into the Church which is erected at the "Virgins Well" & the Sycamour tree where 
who
holy family was while in Egypt, & where 'tis said the Child Jesus was bathed by His Mother.

Friday 14
Entry.130:
Heard 7 o'clock Mass at the Chapel in the Balm Garden at Matarieh. French priest officiated, three of his colleagues were on the altar. I was the congregation.
About the hospital all day. Visited No 1 G. H. at night.Talk withRamsay Smith & Prof Watson.

Saturday 15May 1915
Ride before breakfast, to quaries which are behind the Citadel of Cairo, and the tombs. Captain Plant with me.
Posted letters to The Girls, Mollie, Mrs Knowles, Pearl Drury, The Editor Daily Telegraph, The Minister for Public Information, Sydney, Col. Martin. Pamphlets re Matarieah to Mollie & Mrs Knowles.
At the Jesuits school at Fagala from 4 to 6-15p.m Met the Coptic Patriarch a good holy man not fat.
Cabled to Nash Sydney
Met Captain Bergin from Rosoro Ireland who starts for the Dardanells tonight.

Sunday 16
Entry.131:
At Matarieah forMass at 8 a.m.
Visited the Virgins well & tree.
Not out the remainder of the day.

Monday 17
Entry.132:
Posted subsidiary letter to Mollie.
Letter to Dr Flynn & Senator de Largie. Books on Matarieh to Dr L. Kenny, The Girls, P.J. MacNamara. In Cairo at Post Office, & to Dr Batchelor at his clinique
Hospital all day
Ride between 5.30 & 6-30 p.m,Horse fell on sand opposite hospital & threw me, he went right down on his side.

Tuesday 18May 1915
My horse died this morning
Major Pares here during the morning,he was in France for several months in the R. Horse Guards Blue. Most of his fellow officers were killed.
At D.M. S, office at 6 p.m. saw Major Pares about men returning to Australia

Wednesday 19May 1915
In Cairo during Morning at Anti-robic institute with Father Jesuit & Dr of Science. Went through the place with him.
At Dr Batchelor's female clinique for half an hour.
Letters & papers from Joseph, Kitty Molly. DrDoyle, Hyman, Josie Morris H. L.Harris, Mrs Knowles, Jeroms
At Mena during the afternoon got letters for Jerrom & Self. Papers for self
Letters from Sydney, Melbourne, & England.
All going well here.

Thursday 20May 1915
Went in Motor Car to Mahdhi & Hellowan with Dr Will during morning.
At No 1 G. H. with Jesuit Father at 6 p.m.
Otherwise about the grounds & looking to business

Friday 21May 1915
At Matarieh Church this morning at 7 o'clock. heard Mass. 20 French wounded from the Galipoli peninsula & about 100 
Egypt
 Cairo catholics, all men attended. About 20 received H. Communion.
The head of the Jesuit College in Cairo asked me to be present. Breakfasted with them. A priest delivered a sermon in French during the Mass. At office 9-15 am.
In Heliopolis from 8.30 p.m. to 12 midnight. Williams & 

Saturday 22May 1915
Not out during the day
All going well.

Sunday 23May 1915
At Matarieh Church. St. Famile €“ at 7am. No Mass till 8 a.m. owing to special celebrations for PentecostSunday. Said my prayers look round & back at 8-15 for brkfst.
Went to the Barrages below Cairo, between 4 & 6-30 p.m. Captain Williams & two privates went with me.

Monday 24May 1915
Posted letters to Girls, Mollie, Mrs Knowles, Hyman, Travers, Josie Morris, Doyle & Matareia
h
book. Catholic Press.
In Cairo from 4 to 6 p.m. visiting various business places.
Cable from Girls awaited me at 6p.m. reporting all well.
Wrote to M. M. Bertrand.

Tuesday 25
Entry.133:
Cairo €“ at bank & other place during the morning
At Mena for letters, and to the pyramids & sphinx between 4 & 6-30 pm.
Letters from Mollie dated
Entry.135: April. Papers from Mrs Knowles &Dy T from Girls
Entry.137:
Writing, reading & office all morning.
In Cairo between 4-30 & 6-30 p.m.Dodging round various places.
Writing & reading at night
Entry.139:
Very hot Yesterday & this morning
Lt Col Ramsay Smith here during the morning.
In Cairo during the afternoon from 4.30 pm to 6-30 p.m.
Working in office during most of the day. Practising the typewriter a little.
Entry.141:
A real scorcher this ember day, so it continued from morning until 9 p.m. then some cool air projected into the heat, but not yet to a great degree 11-30 p.m.
At No 1 G.H. talking with Ramsay Smith from 8.30 to 9-30 pm.
Entry.143:
Many men back from Galipoli today.
Atmosphere cool & comfortable this a.m.9.30.15 men left for New Zealand
At Heliopolis at 9 p.m. to Sister Draper from Sydney. She had been to see the Girls just before she left. She & others came in the Kyarra from Sydney. Brought me a small parcel.
Entry.145:
At the Basilica in Heliopolis at 10 am. Mass at a convent in Zeitoun between 5.30 & 6.30pm. A nun from Ireland (African Mission) spoke English
 of the day.
Entry.146:
Posted letters to Girls, Mollie, M. M. Bertram, M.M.Thomas, Senator Pearce.
Busy at office all day.
Old Watson at evening meal.
Captains Williams & plant back from Alexandria.
Entry.147:
In Cairo between 9-30 &11 am
Office work all day
Letters dated
Entry.148:
from 219 Macquarie St & Blackheath.
Not out during Evng
Letters from Arthur, D Wakins &Sen Pearce

Wednesday 2June 1915
Weather as usual. Justfirst thing inmng
Not out all day
Typewriting &c.
Many patients
Entry.149:
In Cairo during the morning
Working rest of the day
Many letters from Home carry dates from 20th Jny 1915 to
Entry.151:
Not out all day
Busy. Office. Reading. Writing.
50 patients in one bunch from Alexandria tonight.

Saturday 5
Entry.152:
Posted letters Watkins, Arthur, Knowles, Armit, Pharmacutical Secty, Victoria
In Cairo, Med school, chemical laboratory &c. between 10 & 12 noon.
Office work. Sleep from 3 to 5 p.m. Wrote to Flowers, Fitzgerald, Usher, Maitland.

Sunday 6
Entry.153:
Posted to Flowers, Fitzgerald, Maitland, Usher, Girls, Paton, & Mrs Fraser.
Mass 10 a.m at Bassilica in Heliopolis. Benidiction at Sisters Church (Africian Mission) at Zeitoun at 7 p.m.

Monday 7
Entry.154:
Usual routine work today
260 patients in hospital
Supper to Captain Williams at night in Heliopolis. Met Dr Brennan who has come from the Dardanelles, he told us something about the fighting, but he appeared to me to be himself mentally upset.
Posted letters to several people at home. Tomlins & others

Tuesday 8
Entry.155:
Letters posted to Bridge,Nan Johnnstone, Jas Roach, Dr Paton, Matron Sherwood
Busy all day admitting & discharging patients.
Wrote to Mrs Thomson (Cooma), Kathleen Bryan, & Sister Blanch Sutcliffe.

Wednesday 9June 1915
103 men sent to Australia by the Kyarra this morning.
Office & 4 
ae
 anaesthetics filled up the day.
Went Heliopolis for Supper. Brasserie de l'avenir.Fish bread and lemonade
Home about 12 midnight.
Entry.156:
Mass here (A.D.B.I.H.) by Father King from Melbourne. About 12 men went to Holy Communion.
Not busy today.
Paid a visit to No1G.H. about 6 p.m., spoke with Ramsay Smith and Barrett, they expect 500 patients tomight.
Entry.158:
About hospital all day.
Not very well. Appetite gone off & interior irregular
Went to Cairo in the tram at 10 p.m., round to Shepheards, back at 12 midnight.

Saturday 12
Entry.159:
In Cairo during morning, Medical School Chemical laboratory, the Citadel, and other places.
Cable 
to
 from & to MacNamaraCable to Buchanan. Sent these from Cairo at 6 p.m. as weekenders

Sunday 13June 1915
Mass at the Basilica Heliopolis at 9-30 a.m.
Not out during the day
Supper at Heliopolis at 11 p.m. Enjoyed it because I was hungry.
Entry.160:
Letters posted to The Girls, Mollie, & Mrs M. M. Knowles.
Very busy all day
In Cairo during the evening from 5-15 to 7 p.m.
Posted letters to

Tuesday 15
Entry.161:
Letter posted to Ned Sheehan
Very Hot today. Flies, small ones, troublous.

Wednesday 16
Entry.162:
Very hotter daytoday. Wind of the hottest & dust galore
At Heliopolis at Night, had Supper at the Brassiere de l'Avenir at 11-15 pm home 12-30 am. on the 17-5-16 Wrote tothe girls.
Entry.163:
Busy all day. Patients in and out. Examining those to be sent to Australia.
Not so hot today.

Friday 18
Entry.164:
Dr Hollywood of W. Maitland brought a parcel & letters from Mollie for me.
Dinner,at 10-30 pm. at Borrills Cafe at Heliopolis €“ Hollywood, Garde, Leary, Plant & others

Saturday 19June 1915
Heaps of patients today
Over 350 in hospital
Letters from MacquarieSt, Maitland, & other places. Dates Febry & up to
Entry.166:
Mass at Basilica (Byzantine Church) at 9-30 a.m. Working hard all day.
Had dinner with Dr Schuber at the Chalet Mena at 7.30 pm.
Entry.167:
1915
Working in the office and about the place today.
Concert at 8 p.m.
Heliopolis at 11 p.m. some roast fowl, potatoes peas. Bananas.
Posted letters to The Girls, Mrs Knowles.
Entry.168:
June1915
Letters for the Girls (supplementry). Dr Paton, MrHennessey, Mollie, Dr Dunn, Clarie Bowen.
In Cairo for an hour during the morning.
Called see Colonel Barrett at night. Had Supper at Heliopolis hotel at 11-30 p.m.
Entry.169:
June1915
Ordinary work for a family of 350 peoplefairly standard. Six small operations.
Surgn Gen Williams called & inspected the hospital, he appeared to be well pleased. Had a whiskey & went away
Heliopolis hotel for Supper at 11 p.m.
Entry.170:
June1915
Kitchiner born.
Ordinary duties about the place.
At Heliopolis between 10-30 & 11-30 pm. Could get no supper
Wrote Strickland & Moroney & SistSutchiffe
Entry.171:
June1915
Inspection by General Maxwell at 9. a.m. All went well. His aids were Prince Hy. of Battenberg and the Marquis of Anglesey, both Lieutents and small men in stature & girth. The G. appeared to be well pleased
Ordinary work during the day
Commenced to have meals by myself prepared by Jerome.
Entry.172:
June1915
At the Medical school at 10 a.m., Stay for about one hour. Dr Colles loaned to me a 1/12in. objective . At theAntirabic institute
Mass at 7 a.m. at the barracks next door.
Ordinary work during the day.
Entry.173:
June1915
Massin a tent in hospital grounds at 7-30 a.m.
At dinner given byLieut Col. Barrett at the Turf Club at 8 p.m. All military men Good dinner Home at 11-30 pm.
Entry.174:
June1915
Letters posted to Girls. Mollie. Strickland. Carruthers. Maxwell.
Working in office.
Reading & writing all day
Entry.175:
June1915
In Cairo this morning. Bank. Med. School. Dep. Public Health.
Posted letters to Dr Paton. To Girls
Cable from MacNamara at 6 p.m.
365 patients in hospital.
Entry.176:
June1915
Cabled Joseph at 6 p.m. for her birth anniversary tomorrow.
A hot day.
Busy.€“ 470 odd patients
Ten letters of
Entry.178:
Joseph's Birth anniversary 
Sent her a cable last night
Very busy all day
Admissions about 80 patients.
Entry.180:
Busy all day
Temperature comfortable
3
 450 odd patients
Entry.182:
Horse at 11 a.m.
Sent off to Australia 131 patients All went well
Captain Plant went to Alexandria
Entry.184:
Not at Mass today
Colonel Manifold here on inspection All was correct.

Monday 5
Entry.185:
35 patients from Alexandria
Busy about hospital all day
Posted letters to The Girls Mrs Knowles, & C P Hyman of London
Letters to 31st May from Girls Buddie & others

Tuesday 6July 1915
In Cairo during morning Letter
s
 posted to Mollie.
Major Bagshaw, Col. Manifold, & Lieut. Col. Barrett here between 5-30 & 7 p.m.
Writing letters to Joseph after evg meal

Wednesday 7July 1915
In Cairo twice today
Cable from and to Mr (The Hon) Meeks of Sydney, about his son Victor.
Close. But all going well.
Wrote to Glen Sparks Goomerri Queensland.
Entry.186:
In Cairoduring the morning.
Ordinary work during the day.
450 patients here

Friday 9
Entry.187:
Ordinary work about the hospital today.
Cable to Meeks Sydney

Saturday 10
Entry.188:
Cable to Girls this morning re MacNamara, Finny & Buchanan
Meeting ay No 1 G. H. Manifold & Barrett

Sunday 11
Entry.189:
Mass at the hospital by Father Richards
About the place nearly all day.
Went to Cairo for Cigarettes at 5-30 pm. Went to the Convent at Zeitoun at 6-30pm.

Monday 12
Entry.190:
Letters posted to Girls, Mollie, C. P. Hyman, Kathleen Bryan. Papers, illustrated, to Mollie.
In town to see a solicitor about Power of attorney for Girls.
Col. Manifold here.

Tuesday 13
Entry.191:
In Cairo during the morning Posted Powerof Attorney to girls. It cost me P.T.525

Wednesday 14
Entry.192:
Cairo 4-30 to 6 p.m.
Letters from Mollie, Kitty, Gn Finn & others

Thursday 15 July 1915
Busy all day about the hospital
550 patients in residence this afternoon

Friday 16July 1915
About hospital all day
2 small operations
All going well
Cable from the Girls: "All well"

Saturday 17
Entry.193:
In Cairo for an hour during the morning.
About hospital
l
 all day
Ken 
Ke
 Garrick & some friends from Melbourne called during evening.

Sunday 18
Entry.194:
Mass Basilica at 9-30 a.m.
Visited church of the Holy Familyat Matarha at 5 pm
Letters to Girls, Mollie, Mrs Reynolds, Strickland, Armit, John Dalley, Doffie & Maggie, Manon, Mrs Rouse, Mrs Garrick,

Monday 19
Entry.195:
Working hard all day at the hospital
Arranging for Englishmen to get away to England.

Tuesday 20
Entry.196:
Got 141 Englishmen away today, 7-45 am
Entrained & all correct
Very hot
Letters from home

Wednesday 21
Entry.197:
In Cairo to see the D.M.S. this morning, in consultation about the O.Cs & other hospital matters
Sleep during the afternoon
Letter writing to Girls & MacNamara at night

Thursday 22
Entry.198:
about hospital all day
Ramsay Smith & some others here

Friday 23
Entry.199:
Working about hospital all day.
Patients flowing in & out
Entry.201:
In Cairo for 1 hour during the morning
About the hospital during the remainder of the day

Sunday 25
Entry.202:
Mass at hospital 7 am
About hospital all day
At Benediction in ConventZeitoun at 7 p.m.spokewith sisters.
Letters posted to Girls. Mollie.MacNamara
Entry.203:
609 patients here today.
All correct
About hospital all day
Letters to Girls, Mollie, Dr ArthurStrickland Kathleen Bryan.

Tuesday 27
Entry.204:
Sent 64 to England today
In Cairo for 1 hour this morning
Letter to the Girls.

Wednesday 28
Entry.205:
Ordinary work about the hospital.

Thursday 29
Entry.206:
Letters to Pearl Drury, & some others.
In Cairo for an hour this morning at chemical laboratory & other places.

Friday 30
Entry.207:
About hospital all day.
The cry is still they come.

Saturday 31
Entry.208:
Pres 658 patients today.
General Legge called this afternoon, about 6 p.m.
Entry.209:
Heard Mass at the Basilica 9.30 am.
Father Vrigille S.J. lunched with me.
Went with the padre to visit a French family at Heliopolis stayed for two hours
Entry.211:
About Hospital all day.
Getting ready to send away a lot of men to Australia.
Letters posted to Girls & Mollie
689 patients here tonight

Tuesday 3August 1915
Sent 369 patients to Australia this morning, they were amenable to discipline and gave no trouble.
Was in Cairo at 12 noon, interview with D.M.S. & General Maxwell. Martin (L.Col.) had sent on my personal letter to Gen. Maxwell.
Mainfold here during the afternoon.
Entry.212:
In Cairo during the morning
116 patients admitted, from Alexandria and locally
Entry.214:
In Cairo during the morning
Hospital all day
Letters from Girls & others
Cables to M.M. Knowles & Roger Arnott

Friday 6
Entry.215:
Dr Maguire from Auckland lere to lunch with me.
I called at Egyptian hospital to see the New Zealand Medicos who are installed there

Saturday 7
Entry.216:
About hospital all day except for one hour in the morning when I 
cal
 was in Cairo. Called at the anti-rabic institute.

Sunday 8
Entry.217:
Mass here at 7 a.m.€“ Father Richards.
at Materieh & Zeitoun
Dr Maguire hereto tea.

Monday 9
Entry.218:
Ted Norrie & Brucle McLachlan here to tea.
Wrote to the Girls,NelJohnson, Pat Watt, Muriel Bridge & others

Tuesday 10
Entry.219:
In Cairo during the morning, at Chemical laboratory and at Antirabic institute.
About hospital rest of the day.
Writing letters at night MrsNorrie.Travers. Paton.

Wednesday 11
Entry.220:
Took Father Vrigille S.J. & some of his colleagues to the Pyramids at Mena this afternoon.
Working in hospital during the day

Thursday 12
Entry.221:
Bairam festival in Cairo today The Mohammadams in their best clothes in the streets.
In Cairo for one hour between 5-30 & 6-30 p.m.
Sent a cable message to the girls, A telegram to Weston, Orsova, Port Said

Friday 13
Entry.222:
About hospital all day.
Letter from Carrie & Mrs Knowles.

Saturday 14
Entry.223:
Everything quiet.
Hospital work going smoothly.

Sunday 15August 1915
At the Basilica for Mass at 9-30 a.m.At the African Mission Convent, Zeitoun, at 7 p.m. for Benediction.
Wrote Knowles, Girls, Mollie.



Monday 16
Entry.224:
In hospital all day
Letters from home
Posted letters to 
Joseph
 The Girls, Mollie, & others

Tuesday 17
Entry.225:
x In Cairo for two hours this ening on business.
In hospital rest of the day

Wednesday 18
Entry.226:
Nothing unusual all day
Hospital routine & treatment

Thursday 19
Entry.227:
Major Purdy of Sydney. Here for lunch with me.
Korno taken by the Germans
Teutons victorious all along the Eastern front

Friday 20
Entry.228:
About hospital all day.
Young Coppin from Elsternwick Victoria took tea with me at 8 p.m.

Saturday 21
Entry.229:
In Cairo during the morning
Heard that Ramsay Smith had left No 1 A.G.H., and that Barrett had been deprived of his posts except the Red Cross business.

Sunday 22
Entry.230:
In Cairo dng mng, saw Ramsay Smith at Sheppheards Hotel.Mass 7 a.m.
Purdy to lunch 
& tea
. Purdy & Paton to tea. Drive round Matereh between 6 & 8 pm..

Monday 23
Entry.231:
Ramsay Smith relieved of his Command at No 1 A.G.H. Why?Barrett relieved of all his Military duties & ordered to confine his energies to Red Cross work. Why? Miss Bell the Matron, formerly, of No 1. A.G.H. is to return to Australia. Why? A real convulsion. I fear some dirty bad work.
Saw Smith & Barrett for a few minutes today.
Col. Paton


Tuesday 24
Entry.232:
In Cairo at Med school & Chemical laboratory during the morning.
Major Purdy to lunch.
Prof Watson to tea.
Placed two men under arrest at 11 p.m., because they brought liquor into the hospital.

Wednesday 25
Entry.233:
In Cairo during the morning
At No 4 A.H. between 9& 10 A.M. Talking with Sister Draper.
Wrote Watkins, de Largie, & Graham (Hon Mm.)
Entry.234:
Col. Manifold lunched with me today.
About hospital during the remainder of the day.
Wild rumours from Galipoli
A paper from Mrs ReynoldsCatholic Press.

Friday 27
Entry.235:
About hospital all day.
All going well.

Saturday 28
Entry.236:
At the Citadelduring the morning.
Visited the Indian hospital and saw the asphalt that is laid upon the sand as flooring for the tents.

Sunday 29
Entry.237:
Took Sister Draper, Captain Cameron, & another officer to Matarieh this evening.
Finished letters to Girls & Mollie.
DrHollywood partook of tea with me.
Entry.238:
300 Australians set out from here for Australia today €“8 am.
x Mrs Ramsay Smith, from Adelaide, called upon me this morning. She looked well
Letters to Girls, Mollie, Strickland, Paton &c

Tuesday 31
Entry.239:
Saw Ramsay Smith & his wife in Cairo this morning. The festive Ramsay looked upset.
At Chemical laboratory.
Sent 270 Australians away today, to be shipped for home.
Entry.240:
Nothing out of the Common
Patients in & out slowly
About hospital all day
Entry.242:
Not out all day.
Major Purdy took tea with me at 8 p.m.
Letters from home to 25th July Car, Joseph, Buddie, Kitty & a lot of friends. Reports good in all ways.
Entry.244:
In Cairo for one hour during the morning.
About hospital rest of the day.

Saturday 4
Entry.245:
Not out all day
Father King from Melbourne partook of tea with me a 7-30 pm He looked after the Roman Catholics during the afternoon.

Sunday 5September 1915
Mass here during the morning, I served.23. Communicants.
At Convent Zeitoun, between 6 & 8 pm.
Entry.246:
At D. M. S. during morning, a chat with L.G. Ford

Tuesday 7
Entry.247:
Chat with L. Gs Baptie& Ford this morning. They said that I should go to Galipoli soon.
Dr Plant left & DrAiken came today
In Cairo during the mng
Major Purdy here.Dr White partook of tea with me

Wednesday 8September 1915
Major Purdy to Lunch.
Dr Schuber called at 7 pm. asked me to go to the Chalet at Mena on Sunday night.
Entry.251:
In Cairo during the morning
At Confession in the Basilica at 8 pm.
About hospital all day

Sunday 12
Entry.252:
The basilica in the morning
The Zeitoun Convt Matarieh between 6 & 8 p.m.

Monday 13
Entry.253:
Prof Watson called about 6 pm
Went with him to Sheppheards hotel & dined with Barrett at 8.30 p.m. Home at 11-30 p.m.

Tuesday 14
Entry.254:
In Cairo this morning for two hours.
Letters from all at home Answd these letters by 2 A.M. 15-9-15

Wednesday 15September 1915
About the hospital all day
Work not being done to my satisfaction by my medical staff.
Entry.256:
About hospital al day,
Nothing particular doing
600 patients today

Saturday 18
Entry.257:
Went with Father Vrigille to Heliopolis to see some of his friends. Had afternoon tea with them, then went for a motor drive.
In Cairo during the evening

Sunday 19
Entry.258:
At Basilica 9-30 am.
Not out otherwise.

Monday 20
Entry.259:
Letters posted to girls
Wrote Watkins, Estell, Doyle, Manon M. Knowles.
Not out all day.

Tuesday 21
Entry.260:
In Cairo this morning.
600 patients today.
Wrote several letters

Wednesday 22
Entry.261:
Examining patients all day today for Australia.
Purdy & Campbell Smith here for lunch

Thursday 23
Entry.262:
About hospital
650 patients
Had dinner with Lieut Col McGlynn ar 
Shep
 the Continental Hotel.

Friday 24
Entry.263:
Saw Lt Col McGlynn, he had come from Galipoli, where he has been since April. He looks very well.
Lunched with Col. Manifold & Col. Hunter at the Continental Hotel.
Entry.264:
In Cairo during the morning.
Sent 128 men to Australia, all correct.

Sunday 26
Entry.265:
At Basilica at 9-30 a.m.
At Matarieh with Major Youngat 6 p.m.
Letters from home this morning.

Monday 27
Entry.266:
Col. Featherstone. P.M.O. for Australia visited the Hospital and made an inspection.
Dined with Mrs Newmarch at the Occidental Hotel.
Spoke with General Ford and some others.

Tuesday 28
Entry.267:
In town this morning called at Chem Laboratory, Med. School, and other places.
Writing, reading & sleeping for the remainder of the day.
Entry.270:
About Hospital all day
Captain Bourke left hospital, as he was ordered for Alexandria.
He was insulting when going away.
Entry.271:
Notification received that I was to hand over hospital to Captain Bourke & that I was to go to Alexandria on Monday the 4th inst.
General Ford called with Major Bagshaw. Had a talk with the General
Entry.273:
In Cairo during morning. Called on General Ford.He took me to General Maxwell.Hadbrief chat with the latter.
Settled up accounts.
Handed over to Captain Bourke at 1 pm.
At Confession in Heliopolis at 8 p.m.

Sunday 3
Entry.274:
Rosary Sunday. Mollie
Communion 7 am at Bassilica Heliopolis.
Packing all day.
At Zeitoun Convt between 6-30 & 8-30 pm.
Clearing up everything.

Monday 4October 1915
Left Cairo at noon today
Arrived Alexandria at 4-30 pm.
Reported to Act.G. 3rd Echelon at 6 p.m.
At Hotel Majestic in Alexandria at 5 pm.
Entry.276:
In Alexandria. Arranged about departure for Mudros & Anzac on Friday.
TelephonedMrs Rudd about letters & papers.
At Mustapha. Ride around in small trams with Jerom.
Ramble round the city at night. Wrote many letters
Bed about midnight

Wednesday 6
Entry.277:
In Alexandria
Went as far as 17. Gen. Hospital, end of the Ramelah tram line.
Between 9 & 11 p.m. rambled round the Native quarter of the city midst lanes, & roads, narrow dirty, at Egyptian music halls playhouses Very interesting but horribly dirty. How is it that some epidemic does not come & Sweep the whole people off the face of the Earth?

Thursday 7
Entry.278:
Had 
cholor
 Anti-choleria vaccine innoculation this evening at Coonvalescent Camp Mustapha. The C.O. there sent me lots of patients when I was at Abbassia
At
At the Sultan Hassan Club during the afternoon.
Wrote to the girls & many others.
At a Music Hall at night. Sick. Did not enjoy it. Bed midnight.

Friday 8
Entry.279:
Letters from Car, Joseph, Kitty (Home from Cessnock on 8th or 9th Septbr) DeLargie and Doffie. Answered them at once.
Some men from the Kanowna ,dined with me tonight. Met Austin Curtin from Bondi Sydney.
At a rotten Musical Show in the evening

Saturday 9October 1915
Writing all the morning.
Lunched on board the Australian Hospital Ship Kanowna with an officer from Hobart. Saw Curtain, Moss, Fluffie Vickards , Hamilton, 
and so
 Featherstone, & some others.
Received orders tojoin the ship Ismailia at 10 a.m. on
Entry.280:
at Quay 45 to cross the Mediterranean. Jerom also.

Sunday 10October 1915
7a.m. Mass at St Catherines.
Mustapha Barracks at 9-15 am.
At Ship Ismailia at 10 a.m. got on board at 1-30 pm.
Left No 45 wharf at 4-30 p.m. Passed throughbreakwater at5.45 p.m. Sea Smooth. Conditions comfortable.
Entry.281:
On S.S. Ismailia. Crossing the Mediterranean Sea from Alexandria for Lemnos & Anzac. All went well. The M.O. of Ship. Jerrom assistant, dispenser, & general handy man.
Inspected ship with Captain & O.C. A far from clean vessel. Flies somewhat abundant. Made report. Sea smooth. Some men uncomfortable. No real sea sickness. About 50 officers on board.
Entry.283:
Dispensing & dressing 9 to 10 a.m. Jerom assistant. Inspection of Ship 10 a.m. Not clean. Live rabbits, hens, & sheep on board.
Hard winds from the North began but all went well
We have no wireless on board Skipper & his staff keep a close look out for Submarines

Wednesday 13October 1915
Stronghead wind from the North still blowingVoyage pleasant. Land on both bows Candy to the East. The Mainland of Greece to the West. We passed between it & the islands ofZea.
About 4 p.m. Submarine Scare. 2ndmate reported to the Captain a submarine in the wake of the ship to the port side. Everyone anxious. Some for'ard put on life belts. Jerrom amongst thenumber
At 11 pm. I was on the bridge with the Captain, Search light on Mudros heads 17 miles in front
I left little before twelve light then 7 miles ahead
Entry.285:
6 a.m. in Mudros harbour. A spacious sheet of almost completely enclosed water, large to accomodate very many ships, now occupied at its uppermost part. We anchored in the outer end Tripple barred entrance, nets and floats. Saw a small French Submarine pass in rear of our ship at 7 am
Anchored far up in Mudros Bay alongside a transport, much larger than our ship.

Friday 15October 1915
About 12 noon was warned to be ready to leave the ship at 2 p.m. All packed by 1 pm. On board the pinnace at 1-55 p.m. Moved away a few minutes after 2 o'clock & were taken across the harbour to a steamer of the 
Kehd
 Kedhevial line€“ the El Kadra €“?€“ Climbed the ladder on board. Left the anchorage about 4 p.m., passed through the nets at about 5 pm. & headed for Anzac. Head wind. Surface of sea roughened.
Left letters on board the Ismailia for home.

Saturday 16October 1915
Arrived Anzac about 1 a.m. Landed and got to bed about 2-30 pm. on a Stretcher. Breakfast 1st Australian Casualty hospital, Major Gordon from Melbourne. Saw Col. Howes D.D.M.S. Nothing for me to do. To stay on at 1.A.C.H. for a few days awaiting events. Wanderon side of the hills all day. Met Fiaschi he took me to the top of the hills to the look outs on left of the line, looked out over Suvla Bay, saw fleet & British trenches opposite Turkish trenches. Looked through a periscope at the Turkish trenches. Met Col. Meredith, from Raymond Terrace. Met several others whom I knew.

Sunday 17
Entry.286:
Did not know about Mass. Forgot 'twas Sunday till too late Went to left of position, met Fiaschi, walked round to different places with him during the morning lunched with him. Rested between 3 & 4-45 pm. Went to right of position Met Charley Cox Lieu. Col.walked round with him, went to hisquarters. Rifle fire & shells all day long. Rifle fire, machine guns & shells at night Saw some shells fall on the hills not far from us when I was with Fiaschi

Monday 18
Entry.287:
Up at 6-30 a.m. Wrote some sheets to the girls
After breakfast walked along the Anzac beach, climbed the hill to the Artillery Head Quarters. Met Col. Chas Cox. Spent the morning with him going through the trenches on the right flank of the position. Was at the most advanced posts with the men of the L.H. Regiments. Spoke with them. Examined the Turkish positions with periscopes, looked through the loopholes, straight on to the Turkish loopholes and sand bags, in some places but 40, 50, or 60 yards distant. Wonderful series oftrenches on both sides. Great men each to exist & fight for so long at this game Afternoon same experience.Great shooting from large & small weapons of both British & Turks. Fired about 40 rounds out of raise rifles at the Turkish loopholes. Gen Ian Hamilton hands over command today.

Tuesday 19
Entry.288:
My Kathleens birthday. Wished to her many happy returns of the day in spirit.
Lunched with Dr (L. Col) Millard. During the afternoon travelled round the trenches with him.
Nothing startling happened today that we know of.

Wednesday 20
Entry.289:
Mass in a dug-out by a priest from Malta, of Maltese birth & education. I served. A Maltese officer & several of his workmen present
With Lt. Col. Millard at 10 a.m €“ Visited Gen. Legge, had a chat with him.He is not well.
Walked round trenches with Millard, found crosses overburial places of Col. MacLaurrin & Col. Onslow-Thompson. Millard took photographs of both.
Talked with Father Fahey & Dr Brennan, they took us through some of the trenches.
Millard photographed graves of Col. Braund & Captain Bage. Writing this at 8 p.m. in dug out
Entry.290:
Around
 Called to see Col. Roth, General Legge, Colonel Holmes, & others this morning.
Around the trenches at Walkers Hill & Russel Top with Col. Lamrock & Major Fitzgerald Was taken to a bomb throwing excavation which was within ten (10) feet of a like place used by the Turks for the same purpose. Into connecting tunnels, undermining tunnels & other passages. Fired some 10 rounds at loopholes in the Turkish sandbags. Men of the
Entry.291: Battalion from New South Wales holding the trenches nearest to the Turkish line. Called see Col Paton in evening.
Entry.292:
A damp day Especially after dark p.m.
Wandering up Monash Gully. Lunch with Colonel Holmes.
Saw two dead Turks. They were of a party that entered the camp during the night between Popes & Quinns posts The others escaped They had bombs, rifles, bayonets. Both shot dead through chest.
Entry.293:
A damp Cold 
morn
 early morning Between 10 A.M. & 1 pm. I was with Lieut Col MacKenzie, & some other officers around Quinns and Popes Post, walking through the trenches looking at the machine guns examining the Turkish Trenches close by in all directions to the Front. Wonderful how the men hold on to these ridges.Lunched with Dr Phipps.Board ship for Mudros at 11-30 pm
Entry.294:
On board a navel transport which plies between Galipoli and Mudras. Passed Imbrasto the North & the Galipoli peninsula on the South, Gaba Tepe Sedul Barr ridge, Achi Baeba, Cape Helles around this into the Dardanelles
9 p.m. On board S.S. Denosthanes bound for Alexandria.
Entry.295:
Steaming South in the first class Steam Ship Demosthenes, of the Aberdeen line.11. A.M.A submarine scare, ship canted by the sudden putting over of the helm.11-30am. A water spout on the portbow, reaching from the clouds to the water.
Rest of the day uneventful.
Passed close by & in the distance many islands. Each with forbidding precipitous sides rising from the sea. Villages.Cultivated areas.
Sea Calm.

Tuesday 26
Entry.296:
Night without incident. Morning none more perfect for atmosphere & Sea.
Steaming in S.S. Demosthenes a zig zag course down the Aegean sea.
Absence of Seabirds remarked. A few species of different kinds of land birds came on to the ship.
Entry.297:
Morning perfect atmospherically & Marinely.
In Alexandria 
a
 Harbour at 9-30 a.m. At wharf at 12-45 p.m. Landed on wharf at 1-45 p.m. At Majestic Hotel 2-30 p.m. Reported Head Quarters Mutapha D.A.A.S. & A.D.M.S. at 5-30 p.m. €“Took Jerrom to Variety show 
at
6 to 7-45 p.m.
Dinner Hotel Majestic 8-15 p.m. Saw Lieut. Col. Christian in his bed-room somewhat sick. Bed. 10 p.m.
Entry.298:
Writing till 11- A.M.
at ry.stn at 11-40 a.m. en route to Cairo. At Shepheards Hotel Cairo at 3-40 p.m. Hot day, pleasant journey. Jerrom wentAbbassia at once for letters & other parcels. He brought some from Kathleen & others. Called upon Mrs Bacon at the National Hotel stayed to dine with her.
Entry.299:
Jerrom brought a letter from Mollie 27.9-15 Those from the other Girls have gone to Lemnos.
Saw Gen. Ford today, he bade me go to No 1 A.G.H. for a time, & that he would have a ship for me after a little.
Lunch with Barrett.Purdy dined with me.
Saw Mrs Newmarch during the evening. Talk with General Ford.
Entry.300:
Orders. "Report for temporary duty to No 1 A.G.H.I shall require your servicesshortly to take charge of invalidsreturning to Australia." Ford.
Arrived No1 A.G.H. at 12-45 a.m. Reported.
Writing, reading & looking roundduring the day.
In Room No 733.
Entry.301:
Mass at Basillica at 9-20 a.m.
Mrs Bacon called at 5 p.m. Showed her the hospital and took her to Matarieh& the ZeitounConvent.
Dined at National hotel with Mrs B. & daughter
Entry.302:
In Cairo during the morning.
Back at 1-45 p.m.
Reading, writing, & sleeping during the afternoon.

Tuesday 2
Entry.303:
All souls day.
Visited Old Cairo today with Drs Henry of Grafton & Cunningham of India. Coptic Churches, one Mosque & the Nilometer.
Letter from CarJoseph. Wrote to them as also to Mrs Keohan & Mrs Ryan.
Entry.304:
Writing during morning.
From 2 till 6-30 p.m. in Cairo 
most
 around the bazaars off the Moushky with Drs Henry, Hollywood and.Felt rather miserable, and about 6 p.m. wretchednoises in ears, rushing in the head, heaviness in legs below the knees, miserable all over, too talkative words flowing correctly & with much facility; worse coming home in tram at dinner wretched, 8 p.m. same but becoming worse inclined to go to bed at 8 p.m., some visitors too talkative to them; during night no sleep a great battle in progress all over body between lucocytes and some invading organism. Passing much urine 6 times in 12 hours, large amount each time. Imagining all sorts of things. 
Not fit to get up for breakfast
. Treat €“Salacine & x grs,. Dormoporde grs.Phenactin xx grs Laxative 3 tabs.
Entry.305:
Unable to be up for breakfast. Sent word to Col. Newmarch. Major(Dr. ) Summons called to 
to
see me about 11 am. Wretched in every way. Temp 100 to 101º during morning Pulse rapid. 4 p.m Still feeling wretched had bath & came down to hospital. Temperature high
t
 and pulse rapid.
Had to purchase Swiss Milk and biscuits for myself
No one has so far,12 midnight to examine me or take my temperature. Summons looked at me three times put his hand on my wrist & said "Youwill be all right."
Entry.306:
7.a.m. A more comfortable night, Some sleep. Wretched all over. Legs week & aching below knee. Pain in head dull heavy. P. 97 to 100. Temp 100 to 101º to 9 am.
Breakfast. Porridge, Swiss Milk, biscuits.
Just like Anzac a thirty six hours fierce battle (Inside me between the lucocytes & the organism), & now 48 hours after settling down to a ding dong struggle. Which side will win
Two watery evacuations Copious & yellow during night, two small during day, some gas and strain after the second.able to read & write off & on during day.
Posted letters home & to MMKnowles.
Entry.307:
4a.m,. Miserable off & on during night. Tongue & mouth becoming dry, the saliva not secreting. Slight continuous headache. Intermittent abd. pain of a mild character. 8p.m. A fairly comfortable day. slight continuous headache. Three attempts at bowel evacuation.One fair evacuation. Desire for food somewhat increased.
Letter from Car, Marion, Beechwood Cottage, Travers & Dr Arthur.
Entry.308:
Slept well all night. Temperature near normal 8 am. Pulse 85
Writing & reading all day.
Sister Stone from Zetland hospital (Mrs O'Conner Matron) brought me knitted sox from Joseph. Not at Mass. Read the Epistle & Gospel for 24thSunday a/)
Entry.309:
Air Temperature ideal this moment 7 a.m.
Left hospital ward at 4 pm. Nearly O.K.
At dinner
Mess meeting after dinner
Walk with Henry Dr after dinner.
Entry.310: As I look out of my window at the central dome of thisgreat building €“ Palace Hotel €“ & note its surroundings of architecture & atmosphere, my mind thinks:- How much a good Architect can do to fit puny art into great Nature?€“
Entry.311:
Met Col. Nicholson in Col. Newmarch's office this morning:He has just come from Sydney, in charge of troops.
In Cairo for a little during the afternoon
Entry.313:
Writing & reading all day.
In Cairo during the afternoon with Dr Henry & two others.

Friday 12November 1915
Posted photographs of Anzac graves €“Onslow Thompson, MacLaurin, Braund, Bage & of the countryto various people:- Holman. The Thompson family, 
Girls
 Mollie, Australian Club President, Col. Geo. Onslow at Anzac, Buckley.
Not out all day
Entry.314: At 9-15 a.m. received ordere, signed by Newmarch, toappear before a Medical board to be boarded for Australia. In same order directed to be ready to leave by train for Suez tomorrow morning for Australia. Board examined me & said that I was not an invalide. Order for packing up & starting tomorrow cancelled about 4-15 p.m. In Cairo during the morning, called to see Dr White & Father Vrigille & said goodbye to them. Fortunately did not send cables to say that I was orderto set out.
Entry.315:
Basilica toMass at 9.30 a.m.
Writing & reading rest of morning.
€‹Took Col. Nicholson & two other officers to Matarieh Church, The Virgins well & tree & the Obelisk at Materieh
Home to dinner. At Zeitoun Convt at 6 p.m.
Entry.316:
Wrote to Gen. Ford telling him that if Col. Martin is agreeable, I am willing to take up my old position at No. 2 A. G. Hospital. Letting byegones be byegones
In Cairo during the morning.
Awalk round Heliopolis between 5 & 6-30 pm.
Writing & reading during rest of the day.
Met Father McAuliffe from Anzac, down stairs at 6.30 p.m.
Entry.317:
In operating room during the morning
Writing & reading
Cairo during the afternoonTram ride to Old Cairo4 Millimes for one hours ride.
Looking at Xray pictures after dinner with two medicoes in my room. Wrote Girls.
Received cable from girls dated 5-11-15
Entry.318:
Reading & writing all day.
In Cairo during the afternoon
Had afternoon tea with Mrs Bacon.
Posted letters to Girls and Hyman.
Entry.319:
Went to Mena with Dr Henry (from Grafton ) & some others.
Climbed the 2nd pyramid & waved the Australian flag upon it €“ Kephren €“
Left Henry & the other men to climb the first pyramid (Cheops) but when I met them again I was told that none of them had reached the top.
Brought some pieces of Alabaster from base of 2d pyramid.
Entry.320:
Board on pyjamas at 12 noon.
Went with Major Brown for a trip past the Citadel, the Sulphur Springs to Old (
deserted
) Cairo, near to the Windmil Hills, & home via Gezeirah & Cairo.
Writing during evng.
Entry.321:
The anniversary of my Fathers death in 1885 R.I.P.€“ Posted letters to Girls, Mollie,M. M. Knowles, Geo Varley, & Pharmtical Journal in Melbourne.
At Andebean's place 6 SharehEl Murah, Heliopolis.
Visit Col. Nicholson at Zeitoun at12-30 p.m.Saw L. Col Nicholson at Zeitoun.
Entry.322:
Mass at 9am at Bassilica
Writing & reading all day.
Visit Col. Nicholson at Zeitoun at 6 p.m. At Convent of the Africian Mission at Zeitoun from 6-30 to 8-30 p.m. Vespers & Benediction.
Entry.323:
Post mortems during the morning
Not out during afternoon or morning
Writing & reading & sleeping during afternoon
Entry.324:
In p.m. room during the morning
At Andebanes for afternoon tea.
Bed 9 p.m.
Entry.325:
P.M. room during morning.
Posted letters to Potts at H. A College Windsor N. S.Wales.
At Zeitoun & Matarieh between 4 & 6 p.m. with Cpts Henry & Black.
13 letters from Australia at 6 p.m. must read them now.
Entry.326: Some arrivals from Australia today, parsons and doctors.
Entry.327:
In p.m. room all the morning.
In Cairo about 4 pm.
At 4-30 pm. met Miss Delohery on the balcony at Shepheards Hotel. Had a talk with her.
A train load of sick & wounded in at 4.30 pm today.

Saturday 27
Entry.328:
Another Morn Aurora rosy daughter of the Dawn has risen with splendour in Egypt
Reading & writing all day.
Entry.329:
At Basilica at 10 a.m. Mass.
Afternoon tea at No 4 Auxillary hospital
Big batch of delayed letters from home, theywent afterme to Lemnos.
Entry.331:
In Cairo last night with Dr Henry & others at a picture show, too sleep to enjoy it, home about 1 A.M.
In Cairo at 10 am. saw Col. Featherstone.
Writing & reading during the rest of the day
Entry.332:
Reading & writing all day.
The coldest day I have felt in Egypt. Wind from the North
Report says that snow is falling at Galipoli.
Entry.333:
No wind this morning
Put on winter clothing today. Too heavy.
In Cairo during the afternoon. Had a chat with Knox who is managing the Red Cross work. He told me 3000 to 4000 Australians in hospital here today as against 7 or 8 thousand some time ago.
Entry.334:
Orders at 10 am. to take Medical Charge of the S.S. Themistocles at Suez for Australia
Preparing all day to set out.
Wrote letters to Hyman, Mrs Reardon, Peck, Sister Sutcliffe, Sister Johnson, Mdm Andebon, Dr Schuber.
Sent cables to Girls & MrsM. M.Knowles.
Everything ready just at midnight.
Entry.335:
Left Cairo 11-30 a.m. for Suez. Arrived Suez 4-30 am
Went on board S.S. Themistocles.
Good ship. Not too many to look after.
30 orderlies about 150 patients.
Entry.336:
Left Suez wharf about 8. am.
A comfortable & agreeable day.
Getting all into working order
Bed 11 p.m.
Entry.337:
Mass 7-30 a.m.
Steaming comfortably down the Red Sea
Ordinary routine work during day
Entry.338:
Travelling South in the Red Sea.
Temperature somewhat high, but easily bearable.
Short Marconi Message posted up.
Distance travelled 306 miles in 24 hrs. 49 mins.
Entry.339:
December 1915
Very hot night yet not unbearable
Wh
Weather fine. Steady head wind all day.
Distance 291 miles. Time 23 hours 50 mins. 5 seconds.
Entry.340:
8 a.m. Almost at the Northern end of the St. of Bab el-Mandeb, where so many tears have been shed during the ages that have gone.
Cool head wind. Sea not rough enough to disturb this big ship.
Served Mass for Father Coleman in the lounge. He told me that it was for me because I had treated him for his sore throat.
8.30 p.m. Off Aden in Gulf of Aden, heading for Cape Gardafui
268 miles. 23 hrs 44 mins 55".
Entry.341:
12 noon. 288 miles. 23 hrs 50 m44 secs.
Steaming due Eastwards all day. sea smooth. Wind cool.
Operation in morning on skull injury.
Playing Bridge at night €“ silly €“
Entry.342:
Rounded Cape Gardafui about 4 am. Heading now for Fremantle.
295 miles.23 - 41€™- 56".
A pleasant day.All went well
Wasted time playing whist at night
Entry.343:
Parade7 a.m.
Aurora, rosy daughter of the Dawn, rose a little after 6 o'clock. Rays tempered by a cool breeze from the South East (Trades?)
309 miles23' - 45"39€™€™€™
Weather good.Everything all right
Entry.344:
299 miles 23' - 44" 24'''Parade 7 am. Mass 7.20 a.m. by Father Coleman.
A hot day with showers. Real tropical.
All going well
Entry.345:
313 miles 24€™- 43" 04€™€™€™
A very hot day.
Glorious sun rise & sunset Massive glouds & golden yellows
Silly! Playing cards till 11 o'clock at night
Entry.346:
330 miles to 12 noon. 23' - 42" - 20€™€™€™
Rain today in fair quantity.
All going well.
Two men seriously sick.
Playing bridge at night. Very Silly!!!
Entry.347:
345 miles. 23' - 44" - 00€™€™€™
Silly all day. Playing deck billiards and cards. Whist & Euchre for Competitions. Silly Ass!!!
Reading rest of day
Entry.348:
306 miles.23'. 44". 07€™€™€™. 
Wind freshened towards night from the South East
All going well
Entry.349:
293. 23' -43" - 52€™€™€™.
A Stiff South East wind & high seas. Would be rough in a small ship.
All going well.

Saturday 18
Entry.350:
275. 25' - 44" - 44€™€™€™
Heavy swell from South all day. Head wind from same direction.
All doing well
Entry.351:
Served Mass 7.20 a.m.in room on 3rd deck.
289 miles23' - 43" 36€™€™€™
Head winds & high seas all day.
Entry.352:
294 m.23' - 43" - 44€™€™€™
Weather ideal.All going well
All going well

Tuessday
Entry.353:
295 23' - 42" - 56€™€™€™
1100 miles to Fremantle.
Head winds, & rough head seacontinuing.
Otherwise all going well
Entry.354:
Winds stronger than yesterday 
sea rougher
288 miles23' - 43" - 28€™€™€™.
812 miles to Fremantle
At1 a.m. received Wireless message asking for information re patients for W. Australia
Southern Cross high in Southern Sky at 11-30 pm.
Entry.355:
Run 305 miles.23' - 40" - 56"'
To Fremantle 506 miles
All going well
Southern Cross high in the Southern sky at 11-30 pm.
Atmosphere & sea propitious.
At 5 p.m. Visited Engine room & boiler room with the Chief engineer.
Entry.356:
A morning of the best in every way
Miles 30923' - 40" - 00"'
To Fremantle 197 miles
Entry.357:
Some alcoholism during the night amongst officers& men.
5-30 am. arrived Fremantle.
12 noon Left Fremantle metMrs Pope Seed wife to Dr Pope Seed of Perth
Entry.358:
Miles 295.23'
Distance to Adelaide = 1035 miles
Passed King Georges Sound about 1 p.m.
Mass 9-20 a.m. Padre Colman. Cold.
Entry.359:
302 miles.23' - 35" - 32"'
Adelaide 738 miles.
A strong wind from the south.Cold Not much sea.
All doing well.
Wind continued all day & into the night
Concert by crew.
Entry.360:
Miles 275. 23' - 37" - 32"'
463 miles to Adelaide.
A moderate Cold wind from the South . Clouds.
Entry.361:
Miles 273 23' - 37" - 44"'
190 Miles to Adelaide
Cold windy day
Islands (Neptune) 5 to8 p.m.
Letters posted to Girls & others
Telegram for the girls

Thursday 30
Entry.362:
Arrived off Adelaide about 5 am.
Newspaperto hand. No special news.
Some officers went on shore to the City
Coal, 300 tons, being put on board.
The S.A invalides disembarked 18
Entry.363:
Left Outer harbour Adelaide about 10.4 am.
12 noon 22 miles 1'- 56" - 0"' 
Fine day. All going well
Back Stairs passage and Bass Straits not boisterous, with a cold head wind.
